title: Epitaph for Zotikos’ son
support: Four joining marble fragments, damaged on the left and below. The larger fragment is set in plaster. Kaibel probably read the inscription intact.

handNote.lettering: Irregular letters: rhomboid Θ, Ο and Ω, angular Μ, ΤΗ in ligature at l. 5. Presence of two ivy leaves at the beginning and at the end of l. 6 (the last one seen by Kaibel)

date._: 2nd century CE or first half of 3rd century CE

provenanceFound._: Found by the Prince of Biscari in 1750 "in un orto del barone delli Ficarazzi vicino le mura della selva del Convento de' pp. Riformati di S. Maria di Gesù".

provenanceObserved._: Observed by Kaibel in Museo Biscari, later by Korhonen in magazzino del cortile, Collezione Biscari (formerly sala VI.77).

Θεοῖς Κατακθονίοις ἱερόν Ζωτικὸς πατήρ ἰδίῳ τέκνῳ μνήμης χάριν ἐποίησεν, ὃς ἔζησεν ἔετη ❦ κη ❦
Text based on photographs Biscari, Torremuzza, Franz: Ἰ(ούλιος) Ζωτικὸς; Ferrara, Kaibel, Korhonen: Ζωτικὸς Biscari, Ferrara, Kaibel, Korhonen τέκνῳ; Torremuzza, Franz: τέκνῃ ΕΕΤΗ lapis (although Korhonen reports FFTH, considering this linguistic interference; the reading is unclear from photograph due to modern repainting of letters) Biscari, Torremuzza, Ferrara, Franz, Kaibel could see a Η and a second ivy leaf at line end, now lost.

Sacred to the subterranean deities. Zotikos, the father, made it for the sake of the memory for his own child, who lived for 27 years.

Sacro alle divinità sotterranee. Zotico, il padre, ha realizzato per la memoria di suo figlio, che visse 27 anni.

This pagan epitaph is influenced by Latin: in addition to the expression Θ(εοῖς) Κ(αταχθονίοις) ἱ(ερόν) (modelled on D(iis) M(anibus) s(acrum)), an unusual structure for Sicilian Greek inscriptions occurs, in which the invocation to the underworld spirits is followed by the name of the dedicant (often with an attribute), by the name of the deceased in dative, by the dedication verb and by the age of the deceased (see Korhonen 2004: 88). In this case, the relative pronoun introduces the age of the deceased with a costructio ad sensum since the gender of the referent (τέκνον) and the relative pronoun do not correspond. The use of τέκνον to indicate the deceased, who died at the age of 27, is also peculiar: on the use of τέκνον in other epitaphs from Catania, generally referring to children, see IMusCatania 67 = ISic001306, IMusCatania 140 = ISic003260. On the use of ἴδιος as a possessive pronoun, see also IG 14.485 = ISic001308.
